content.body: bakkot: I'd like to recommend some modifications to TR/104. Do you know who I can talk to about that?
content.formatted_body: bakkot: I'd like to recommend some modifications to TR/104. Do you know who I can talk to about that?

content.body: jugglinmike: I would _guess_ that it's owned by TC39 as a whole, so the way to modify it is probably to present a proposal to the committee in plenary asking for consensus for the modification
content.formatted_body: jugglinmike: I would guess that it's owned by TC39 as a whole, so the way to modify it is probably to present a proposal to the committee in plenary asking for consensus for the modification

content.body: But I don't actually know for certain; TR/104 hasn't been updated in a while, so I'm not as familiar with what the process ought to be
Thanks! I think I'll ping the chairs, as well, just to be sure
Does anyone have insight into why Generator and AsyncFunction were made separate types from Function?
content.formatted_body: Does anyone have insight into why Generator and AsyncFunction were made separate types from Function?

content.body: if you just mean "exist as separate objects", Generator objects need to inherit from the Generator prototype to have `.next`, which should not be on regular functions
content.formatted_body: if you just mean "exist as separate objects", Generator objects need to inherit from the Generator prototype to have .next, which should not be on regular functions

content.body: also, they allow you to dynamically construct a generator or async function from source text, although doing so is ev[ai]l and should be shunned

Ah, yeah, right—`.next`. And yeah, that’s what I meant.
Was AsyncFunction separated as a separate type from Function just to parallel Generator?
content.formatted_body:
Ah, yeah, right—.next. And yeah, that’s what I meant.
Was AsyncFunction separated as a separate type from Function just to parallel Generator?
